43.text: The  tenement  overlies  the  Bryah  and  Padbury  Palaeoproterozoic  groups  of  rocks.

44.text: The Bryah Group is divided into the lower Narracoota Formation Volcanics and the

45.text: upper  Horseshoe  Formation  and  is  interpreted  as  a  rift-basin  succession.  The

46.text: Robinson  Range Formation sediments  of  the  Padbury  Group  run  down the  eastern

47.text: side  of  the  tenement  and  the  northern  part  is  dominated  by  rocks  of  the  Wilthorpe

48.text: and Labouchere Formations (also of the Padbury Group).

 The  tenement  overlies  the  Bryah  and  Padbury  Palaeoproterozoic  groups  of  rocks. 
 The Bryah Group is divided into the lower Narracoota Formation Volcanics and the 
 upper  Horseshoe  Formation  and  is  interpreted  as  a  rift-basin  succession.  The 
 Robinson  Range Formation sediments  of  the  Padbury  Group  run  down the  eastern 
 side  of  the  tenement  and  the  northern  part  is  dominated  by  rocks  of  the  Wilthorpe 
 and Labouchere Formations (also of the Padbury Group).  
 The  Horseshoe  Formation  is  present  and  is  generally  comprised  of  ferruginous, 
 manganiferous  and  calcareous  and  also  include  cherts  and  iron  formation.  Also 
   These  sediments  are  partly 
 chloritic  shales  and  quartz-feldspar  wacke. 
 present  in  the  area  are  ultramafics  and  ultramafic  schists  of  the  Naracoota 
 The  main  period  of  deformation  is  associated  with  the  Capricorn  Orogen  (2.2  to 
 1.6Ga) with the Padbury Group interpreted as a peripheral foreland basin succession 
 developing over the Bryah Group.

text:
Lag sampling was conducted originally on a 400m x 400m grid across the majority of 
 tenement  area  (excluding  areas  previously  adequately  sampled  by  other 
 companies). Zones identified as anomalous for Au were subsequently infilled to 100m x 
 100m. Five main areas of anomalism were identified as a result of this program: Wood 
 Creek; Rudds Ridge; Rudds Ridge East; Bare Flat; and Doorah (Figure 3).

text:
During  the  late  1960’s,  Griffin  Coal  Mining,  explored  without  success  for  gold  and 
 copper over a large area of the Padbury and Bryah Groups. 
 Amoco  Minerals  (1979)  and  Electrolytic  Zinc  (1981-1982)  found  no  gold  or  base 
 Hunter Resources, Horseshoe Gold Mines and Lac Minerals explored for gold from 
 1985-1990 on their Sleepy Hollow Project. Sleepy Hollow Well lies to the south of the 
 Mt Padbury Project. Rock chip results to 0.27ppm Au and RAB drilling (best 4m @ 
 0.2ppm Au) were reported. Dominion Mining completed follow up  work in 1993. No 
 Giralia Resources in 1989 tested the Burrows Prospect. The prospect lies to the east 
 of the project. RC drilling returned up to 1m @ 0.33ppm Au. 
 Homestake  completed  detailed  work  on  their  Millidie  Project  in  1989.  Their  project 
 area was situated to the east of E52/1529. Rock chip sampling returned a number of 
 assays above 1 ppm Au. The best assay reported was 1.73 ppm from quartz veining. 
 Regional soil sampling outlined a number of low order anomalies. The main anomaly 
 correlates  with  the  anomalous  rock  chips.  Follow  up  RAB  drilling  of  the  surface 
 anomalism returned up to 4m @ 1.61 g/t Au.

20.text: During  1994,  Sabminco,  King  Mining  and  Valiant  Consolidated  completed  stream

21.text: sediment sampling around the Mt Fraser-Millidie manganese deposits for gold. Three

22.text: drainages were highly anomalous. Values include 46ppb, 55ppb and 585ppb Au. The

23.text: results do not appear to have been followed up.

25.text: In  1996,  Plutonic  Operations  Ltd.  completed  wide  spaced  RC  drilling  within  the

26.text: Robinson Range Formation. No mineralisation was reported.

Homestakes Millidie project as well as ground to the west and south. Extensive soil 
 sampling  and  RAB  drilling  failed  to  find  further  mineralisation.  The  Millidie  Creek 
 project focussed on ground to the northeast of the Homestake Millidie project that lies 
 on  the  same  trend  as  the  Burrows  prospect,  extensive  RAB  drilling  delineated  two 
 low order anomalies. One hole returned 8m @ 0.17ppm Au and another returned 4m 
 North  Ltd.  joined  Curtin  Mining  in  1993  to  explore  the  Feathercap  prospect.  The 
 prospect  lies  to  the  southeast  of  the  project  area.  A  large  area  of  altered  flat  lying 
 shales returned significant rock chip results (up to 12.4ppm Au). RAB and RC drilling 
 followed,  with  the  best  RAB  intercept  of  4m  @  0.31g/t  Au  EOH,  and  the  best  RC 
 During  1994,  Sabminco,  King  Mining  and  Valiant  Consolidated  completed  stream 
 sediment sampling around the Mt Fraser-Millidie manganese deposits for gold. Three 
 drainages were highly anomalous. Values include 46ppb, 55ppb and 585ppb Au. The 
 results do not appear to have been followed up. 
 In  1996,  Plutonic  Operations  Ltd.  completed  wide  spaced  RC  drilling  within  the 
 Robinson Range Formation. No mineralisation was reported. 
 6  EXPLORATION COMPLETED 
 Independence Group NL collected and assayed a total of 100 soil samples during the 
 reporting  period.  The  samples  were  collected  at  a  depth  of  approximately  0.3m  in 
 order to attempt to reduce the effect of recent surface accumulations of anomalous 
 material.  The sample spacing was 100m X 25m with assays undertaken for Au, Ag, 
 As,  Bi,  Cu,  Mn,  Ni,  Pb,  Sb  and  Zn.  Sampling  was  planned  to  be  more widespread 
 than was conducted, however due to the depth of obviously transported material in 
 the drainage areas the programme was truncated. 
 The sampling was designed to further delineate potential mineralisation at the Wood 
 Creek Anomaly (Figures 2 and 3).  A peak value of 24.1ppb Au was obtained. The 
 sampling did not focus anomalism particularly well but did confirm previous results. 
   5

23.text: Reconnaissance  style  geological  mapping  was  undertaken  over  the  Wood  Creek

24.text: prospect area. Details of findings are presented below.

25.text: The high order gold in soil response towards the south of the anomaly is coincident

26.text: with  an  alluvial  system  that  drains  a  meta-sediment  package  that  includes  an

27.text: quartzite unit to the north-east (Figure 4). The quartzite unit forms part of a package

28.text: of  meta-sediments  that  includes  talc-chlorite  schist,  shale  and  inter-bedded  BIF

29.text: horizons. To the west of this low ridge, a dolerite dyke crops out.

30.text: The  talc-chlorite  schist  crops  out  sporadically  over  approximately  500m  and  has  a

31.text: very strong foliation that dips steeply to the east. The southern most line of historical

32.text: drilling almost exclusively intersects this unit.

33.text: To the east of the schist is a fine grained massive quartzite unit. The unit forms a low

34.text: ridge trending 340°-350° and is ~20 – 30m thick and 250m long. The rock has a fine

35.text: sugary  texture  and  breaks  down  to  a  fine  siliceous  powder  when  hammered.

36.text: Sporadic milky quartz veins to 100mm occur, normal to the dominant ~ N-S foliation

37.text: in the area, along the length of the quartzite. Further to the north (~ 500m) the unit

39.text: East of the quartzite is a large package of sub-cropping shales sparsely inter-bedded

40.text: with thin bands of BIF. The shale is finely laminated (5 – 10mm) and strongly foliated

41.text: parallel to bedding (sub-vertical trending ~340°-350°). The BIF bands tend to be less

42.text: than 200mm thick with alternating chert bands to 20mm. Little veining or alteration is

43.text: noted in this unit and Au anomalism abruptly ends within it.

44.text: Approximately 200m to the west of the low lying ridge of quartzite is a ?dolerite dyke

45.text: that  sub-crops  through  the  alluvial  cover.  The  dyke  is  approximately  30m  wide

46.text: (perhaps thinner) and appears to be co-incident with an interpreted 110° structure.

47.text: A series of ~110° structures are interpreted to have been dextrally displaced by the

48.text: quartzite by approximately 10 – 15m. Some large quartz veins have been observed

text:
Two  samples  of  float  material  were  taken  at  the  Bare  Flat  prospect.  A  maximum 
 Reconnaissance  style  geological  mapping  was  undertaken  over  the  Wood  Creek 
 prospect area. Details of findings are presented below. 
 The high order gold in soil response towards the south of the anomaly is coincident 
 with  an  alluvial  system  that  drains  a  meta-sediment  package  that  includes  an 
 quartzite unit to the north-east (Figure 4). The quartzite unit forms part of a package 
 of  meta-sediments  that  includes  talc-chlorite  schist,  shale  and  inter-bedded  BIF 
 horizons. To the west of this low ridge, a dolerite dyke crops out. 
 The  talc-chlorite  schist  crops  out  sporadically  over  approximately  500m  and  has  a 
 very strong foliation that dips steeply to the east. The southern most line of historical 
 drilling almost exclusively intersects this unit.  
 To the east of the schist is a fine grained massive quartzite unit. The unit forms a low 
 ridge trending 340°-350° and is ~20 – 30m thick and 250m long. The rock has a fine 
 sugary  texture  and  breaks  down  to  a  fine  siliceous  powder  when  hammered. 
 Sporadic milky quartz veins to 100mm occur, normal to the dominant ~ N-S foliation 
 in the area, along the length of the quartzite. Further to the north (~ 500m) the unit 
 East of the quartzite is a large package of sub-cropping shales sparsely inter-bedded 
 with thin bands of BIF. The shale is finely laminated (5 – 10mm) and strongly foliated 
 parallel to bedding (sub-vertical trending ~340°-350°). The BIF bands tend to be less 
 than 200mm thick with alternating chert bands to 20mm. Little veining or alteration is 
 noted in this unit and Au anomalism abruptly ends within it.  
 Approximately 200m to the west of the low lying ridge of quartzite is a ?dolerite dyke 
 that  sub-crops  through  the  alluvial  cover.  The  dyke  is  approximately  30m  wide 
 (perhaps thinner) and appears to be co-incident with an interpreted 110° structure.  
 A series of ~110° structures are interpreted to have been dextrally displaced by the 
 quartzite by approximately 10 – 15m. Some large quartz veins have been observed

8.text: consists of a variably sericite – silica altered fine – medium grained massive wacke.

9.text: The  wacke  beds  generally  dip  75°  to  85°  towards  the  west.  A  bedding  parallel

10.text: foliation  is  well  developed  and  crosscut  by  a  second  cleavage  normal  to  bedding

11.text: (sub-vertical).  This  second  structure  fosters  the  development  of  boudinaged  quartz

12.text: veins  (up  to  200mm)  that  crosscut  bedding.  The  quartz  veins  are  generally  milky-

13.text: white  to  grey  and  focus  zones  of  sericite  ±  silica  alteration  and  can  be  vughy  and

14.text: infilled with limonite. A related (or possibly later?) phase of quartz veins produces a

15.text: moderately intense stock-work in some areas. More intense zones of shearing (to 1 –

16.text: 2m  trending  ~  E-W)  occur  infrequently  along  the  unit.  Veining  and  associated

17.text: alteration  are  most  intense  over  a  strike  length  of  approximately  200m.  Outcrop

18.text: disappears  under  cover  to  the  north  and  crops  out  again  150m  away.  This  second

19.text: area is less veined and altered but is similar to the main zone in overall character. To

20.text: the south, the main area of outcrop appears displaced to the east by approximately

21.text: 50m along an interpreted strike slip fault that is expressed as a creek.

22.text: The  hanging-wall  package  of  sediments  is  dominated  by  inter-bedded  shales,

23.text: siltstones  and  minor  BIF  horizons.  This  more  fissile  package  of  metasediments

24.text: displays  “pencil”  structures  related  to  the  crosscutting  foliation.  The  shales  have

25.text: approximately 5 – 10mm laminates and can be tightly folded, the siltstone inter-beds

26.text: are  generally  more  massive.  The  BIF  inter-beds  fold  tightly  in  places  and  have

27.text: alternating  chert  bands  up  to  20  –  30mm.  Minor  faults  associated  with  tight folding

28.text: are  present trending ~ E-W  within  the  package.  There  is  little  quartz  veining  in  this

30.text: To the east of the wacke unit is the footwall package that consists predominantly of

31.text: inter bedded BIF, shales and siltstones. The footwall rocks are essentially identical to

32.text: those in the hanging-wall except that BIF is by far the most widespread lithology. The

33.text: BIF  packages  are  generally  highly  distorted  and  isoclinal  to  overturned  folding  is

34.text: common. Minor quartz veining is present in isolated zones within the BIF.

40.text: Ground  magnetic  surveys  were  conducted  at  three  of  the  prospect  areas:  Wood

41.text: Creek; Doorah; and Bare Flat (Appendix 2, 3, 4). Lines were 100m apart and were E-

42.text: W at Wood Creek  and  Bare Flat  and  N-S  at  Doorah. The  surveys  were  completed

43.text: using a GEM Systems continuous reading caesium vapour magnetometer with inbuilt

text:
consists of a variably sericite – silica altered fine – medium grained massive wacke. 
 The  wacke  beds  generally  dip  75°  to  85°  towards  the  west.  A  bedding  parallel 
 foliation  is  well  developed  and  crosscut  by  a  second  cleavage  normal  to  bedding 
 (sub-vertical).  This  second  structure  fosters  the  development  of  boudinaged  quartz 
 veins  (up  to  200mm)  that  crosscut  bedding.  The  quartz  veins  are  generally  milky-
 white  to  grey  and  focus  zones  of  sericite  ±  silica  alteration  and  can  be  vughy  and 
 infilled with limonite. A related (or possibly later?) phase of quartz veins produces a 
 moderately intense stock-work in some areas. More intense zones of shearing (to 1 – 
 2m  trending  ~  E-W)  occur  infrequently  along  the  unit.  Veining  and  associated 
 alteration  are  most  intense  over  a  strike  length  of  approximately  200m.  Outcrop 
 disappears  under  cover  to  the  north  and  crops  out  again  150m  away.  This  second 
 area is less veined and altered but is similar to the main zone in overall character. To 
 the south, the main area of outcrop appears displaced to the east by approximately 
 50m along an interpreted strike slip fault that is expressed as a creek.  
 The  hanging-wall  package  of  sediments  is  dominated  by  inter-bedded  shales, 
 siltstones  and  minor  BIF  horizons.  This  more  fissile  package  of  metasediments 
 displays  “pencil”  structures  related  to  the  crosscutting  foliation.  The  shales  have 
 approximately 5 – 10mm laminates and can be tightly folded, the siltstone inter-beds 
 are  generally  more  massive.  The  BIF  inter-beds  fold  tightly  in  places  and  have 
 alternating  chert  bands  up  to  20  –  30mm.  Minor  faults  associated  with  tight folding 
 are  present trending ~ E-W  within  the  package.  There  is  little  quartz  veining  in  this 
 To the east of the wacke unit is the footwall package that consists predominantly of 
 inter bedded BIF, shales and siltstones. The footwall rocks are essentially identical to 
 those in the hanging-wall except that BIF is by far the most widespread lithology. The 
 BIF  packages  are  generally  highly  distorted  and  isoclinal  to  overturned  folding  is 
 common. Minor quartz veining is present in isolated zones within the BIF. 
 Ground  magnetic  surveys  were  conducted  at  three  of  the  prospect  areas:  Wood 
 Creek; Doorah; and Bare Flat (Appendix 2, 3, 4). Lines were 100m apart and were E-
 W at Wood Creek  and  Bare Flat  and  N-S  at  Doorah. The  surveys  were  completed 
 using a GEM Systems continuous reading caesium vapour magnetometer with inbuilt

7.text: Gold anomalism at Wood Creek has been shown to be consistent and of high tenor.

8.text: There is abundant cover in the area and as such the true source of the anomalism is

9.text: uncertain.  Similarly,  the  Au  anomalism  located  at  Bare  Flat  and  Doorah  is  possibly

10.text: sourced from undercover and at this stage is not adequately tested. A shallow RAB

11.text: drilling program will take place later in 2006.

13.text: An Aboriginal Heritage  Survey and Agreement has been obtained from the Jidi Jidi

text:
Gold anomalism at Wood Creek has been shown to be consistent and of high tenor. 
 There is abundant cover in the area and as such the true source of the anomalism is 
 uncertain.  Similarly,  the  Au  anomalism  located  at  Bare  Flat  and  Doorah  is  possibly 
 sourced from undercover and at this stage is not adequately tested. A shallow RAB 
 drilling program will take place later in 2006.
